item.title: Passwords have problems, but passkeys have more
item.description: We had originally planned to go all-in on passkeys for ONCE/Campfire, and we built the early authentication system entirely around that. It was not a simple setup! Handling passkeys properly is surprisingly complicated on the backend, but we got it done. Unfortunately, the user experience kinda sucked, so we ended up ripping it all out...

item.title: EQL - EVM Query Language
item.description: EQL is a language that allows you to query the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) using a SQL-like syntax. It is designed to be the simplest way to ask blockchain questions and get answers.

item.title: Trust takes time
item.description: Today’s websites and apps are built to compensate for an absence of trust, rather than to support its growth. Customers and companies both understand that human handshakes no longer scale in the digital age, and surrender to their replacement by a tap of the finger on a button labeled I accept. While every handshake comes with an expectation of honesty, this button never did: we know we are lying the moment we touch it, as does the author of the legalese no one expects anyone to read. Navigating a trustless world is a heavy price to pay for the boundless freedoms of the World Wide Web—except it doesn’t have to be like this. Although trust remains an inherently human relationship, machines can help us build and evolve our relationships by handling the fiddly bits on our behalf. This liberates people to refocus on gaining mutual value from our relationships, without the huge burden of their setup and maintenance. Everything starts with the realization that data technology is fundamentally trust technology, and thus a transversal layer within any ecosystem rather than just the icing on the cake.
item.author: (Ruben Verborgh)

item.title: Generating images from css-doodle code
item.description:
For the past week, I've been working on a command-line tool to generate images from css-doodle source code. If you're familiar with command lines, try installing it with npm:
npm i -g @css-doodle/cli

item.title: Ricky Mondello » Consider Slowing Down When Switching Password Managers
item.description: Important Note: Although I work at Apple and am deeply involved in the creation of its new Passwords app, in this post I am speaking only for myself and not for Apple. There is no “news” in this post, or any kind of “inside scoop”. My intention is to help the kind of person who would read a blog post about password managers think about and manage their credential data better.

item.title: Tobiko - dbt: Incremental but Incomplete
item.description: Earlier this month, dbtTM launched microbatch incremental models in version 1.9, a highly requested feature since the experimental insert_by_period was introduced back in 2018. While it's certainly a step in the right direction, it has been a long time coming.

item.title: sqlite3 WebAssembly & JavaScript Documentation Index
item.description: This site is home to the documentation for the SQLite project's WebAssembly- and JavaScript-related APIs, which enable the use of sqlite3 in modern WASM-capable browsers. These components were initially released for public beta with version 3.40 and will tentatively be made API-stable with the 3.41 release, pending community feedback.

item.title: Coffee and Open Source Conversation - Jamie Taylor
item.description:
Jamie is a software developer with 14 years' experience, a Microsoft MVP, "Most Visionary Software Development & Consultancy Managing Director" awardee for 2023, and a skilled podcaster with 5 years in engaging content creation.
With a versatile tech toolkit, Jamie crafts tailored solutions, while his MVP status showcases his community commitment. His visionary leadership drives excellence, and his podcasting journey reflects his prowess in relatable communication. An inspiring multi-faceted professional, Jamie embodies dedication, innovation, and impactful change.

item.title: A Sneak Peek at CSnakes: Embed Python code in .NET Apps
item.description:
James is joined by Anthony from the Python Cloud Advocacy team at Microsoft to talk about his latest experiment to help .NET developers leverage Python code and libraries in their apps!
Chapters: 00:00:00 Introduction 00:06:34 Integration of Python and C# into .NET Projects 00:12:20 Integration of Tensor Span in Python and .NET 00:16:53 Demonstration and Discussion on Python Integration in .NET 00:23:13 Functionality of SKLearn and .NET API in Python 00:29:56 Integration of Postgres and Python in .NET Aspire 00:35:38 Database Integration and Tracing in Python Applications 00:40:58 Python Log Analysis and API Trace in Development
Resources: CSnakes project: https://tonybaloney.github.io/CSnakes/ Register for .NET Conf: https://dotnetconf.net

item.title: A Natural Path to Domain-Driven Design (evolve your code)
item.description:
Want to master Clean Architecture? Go here: https://bit.ly/3PupkOJ Want to unlock Modular Monoliths? Go here: https://bit.ly/3SXlzSt Join a community of 1000+ .NET developers: https://www.patreon.com/milanjovanovic
Learn how to naturally evolve your codebase from a basic transaction script to a robust Domain-Driven Design implementation. This step-by-step guide demonstrates practical refactoring techniques, helping you improve code quality, maintainability, and alignment with business logic. Perfect for developers looking to level up their architecture skills without starting from scratch.
Refactoring From an Anemic Domain Model To a Rich Domain Model https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog/refactoring-from-an-anemic-domain-model-to-a-rich-domain-model
How To Use Domain Events To Build Loosely Coupled Systems https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog/how-to-use-domain-events-to-build-loosely-coupled-systems
From Transaction Scripts to Domain Models: A Refactoring Journey https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog/from-transaction-scripts-to-domain-models-a-refactoring-journey
Check out my courses: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/courses
Read my Blog here: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog
Join my weekly .NET newsletter: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech
Chapters 0:00 Reviewing the code 3:21 Exploring the Meeting entity 5:14 Aggregate root: Invariants 10:42 Performance improvements 13:20 Encapsulating nested entities - #1 19:07 Encapsulating nested entities - #2 23:45 Business rules and encapsulation
